Instrument.name: SPATIAL INFRARED IMAGING TELESCOPE
Instrument.description:
Instrument Overview =================== The Spatial Infrared Imaging Telescope (SPIRIT III) was a 33cm clear-aperture off-axis telecope that contained two focal-plane instruments: a multispectral high spatial resolution (18') radiometer and a six-channel high spectral resolution (R~20cm-1), 2.5 to 28 micron Fourier transform spectrometer. The radiometer had four broad spectral bands (A, C, D, and E) and two narrow bands (B1 and B2). Detector pixels were square with a pixel scale of 18.3 arcsec/pixel.

SPIRIT III flew on the Midcourse Space Experiment (MSX) satellite which was launched in April 1996, and operated until February 1997 when it ran out of cryogen.
Further details about the SPIRIT III instrument may be found in the following papers:
